title: What will be the Bank of England's Bank Rate on 1 April 2019?
preds: Just a couple days left so going all in.
The monetary committee votes this month to keep the rates. 100 % chance it will stay the same until April the 1st.
The March 22nd meeting concluded without a rate increase
"The bank’s Monetary Policy Committee voted unanimously to keep interest rates at 0.75 per cent on Thursday (21 March)" [1] [1] https://www.ft.com/content/1f0018ac-4bd1-11e9-8b7f-d49067e0f50d

BOE is leaving interest rate unchanged. 
https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/2019/march-2019

https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2019/mar/21/bank-of-england-brexit-uk-retail-sales-sterling-business-live
...inter alia.  no more meetings before 1 april unless there is some dire and completely unforeseen emergency.
Next meeting this week Thursday. Likely to stay put in this uncertainty period.
UK equities running a bit hot now (EWU 5-month ROC > 3%), increasing probability of a raise.

next MPC meeting is 21st of March.   Even if there is a deal by 21st March (20-25 percent chance, in my view), Brexit itself is likely to be delayed until just before the EP elections.  Hard to see the BOE hiking rates in March before they really know how the economy reacts to the change, though they probably will hike rates in May.  As to cutting rates, it is possible that the BOE could cut on 21 March if a hard Brexit is a certainty by then (extremely unlikely) and it is possible the BOE could do an "emergency" rate cut on 29 March if there is a hard Brexit right at the wire  (even the the BOE has been trying to dissuade the market of the odds of a cut in a no deal scenario), but I put that chance at less than 10 percent.

A number of indicators show that the UK economy is slowing in line with the global downturn and Brexit uncertainty is affecting the market. I don't see a reason for the BOE to adjust the rate up or down, at least not this month, and add to the commotion of the UK economy. [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/business-47414916?intlink_from_url=https://www.bbc.com/news/topics/clm1wxp5378t/uk-economy&link_location=live-reporting-story
[2] https://www.ft.com/content/64163322-38f3-11e9-b72b-2c7f526ca5d0

Bank of England more likely than not to cut rates in no-deal Brexit
Governor Mark Carney confirms shift in stance in evidence to MPs
https://www.ft.com/content/1681d74c-39c5-11e9-b72b-2c7f526ca5d0

BoE has signaled a need for projected stability going into Brexit. May has also recently signaled that the deadline may come and go without an agreement being signed so it would seem this projection of stability may be more important going forward. If there is a an issue with the GBP due to Brexit, it seems more likely that the BoE would ease rather than tighten.
I'm for a cut.  This better reflects my rationale.  See prior forecast

Future implied probability of no change is 98% by the market. 
Financial analysts postpone hikes but no one is forecasting a cut.
I think recent macro indicators signal increased weakness.  I believe Brexit will be put off beyond march 29th only extending uncertainty in time, leading to less investment and consumption... forcing the BoE to cut rates 25 bps...
Pound will crash on hard Brexit

Affirming forecast, even though if I plug my updated numbers for deal/no deal, on time/delayed Brexit from this forecast https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/827143 into my existing decision tree, I get 11, 82, 7 for the three middle buckets. Although a no deal Brexit seems to have become more likely, the timing of the next MPC meeting taking place before it is clear whether the UK will leave the EU on 29 March still lends support to a scenario of an unchanged Bank Rate.

Communication from the recent MPC meeting indicates that the BoE is set to hold its course of 'an ongoing tightening of monetary policy over the forecast period, at a gradual pace and to a limited extent' (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/2019/february-2019) . The last MPC meeting before the end date of the question is on 21st March (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/news/2018/september/monetary-policy-committee-dates-for-2019). I don't expect a change in course then, because I think we would be in one of these scenarios: 
1) there is a Brexit deal in place and forecasts assuming an orderly Brexit will still be valid
2) Brexit has been delayed already, forecasts will also be valid
3) if no deal is still looming, the BoE will not move before it is clear that a no deal Brexit is going to happen.

https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/2019/february-2019
"UK economic growth slowed in late 2018 and appears to have weakened further in early 2019. This slowdown mainly reflects softer activity abroad and the greater effects from Brexit uncertainties at home"
"CPI inflation fell to 2.1% in December and is expected to decline to slightly below the MPC’s 2% target in the near term"
Too much uncertainty to with Brexit fro the BOE to act and signal the wrong sentiment to the market. Wish this question was for the May meeting...that'd be interesting

Governor Mark Carney and his fellow interest rate-setters are expected to keep borrowing costs on hold at 0.75 percent on Thursday, with Britain at risk of leaving the European Union just 50 days later without a transition deal in place to ease the shock. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-boe/first-brexit-now-global-slowdown-to-weigh-on-bank-of-england-idUSKCN1PQ54V?il=0

2/07: Bank of England policymakers voted unanimously to hold the Bank Rate at 0.75% and indicated that there would be fewer increases in borrowing costs in 2019 as the UK economy faces the weakest economic growth in 10 years amid persistent concerns about Brexit and a global slowdown.

The MPC is going to meet on Thursday 7th Feb 2019 (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/news/2018/september/monetary-policy-committee-dates-for-2019). For this meeting, uncertainty around brexit makes it almost certain that rates will remain on hold. This article has some good discussion on the topic: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-30/brexit-will-probably-split-boe-policy-makers-on-how-to-respond
That leaves the meeting on 21 March, and the key question here is: What new information will be available by then about brexit and the UK economy in general that has an influence on the bank rate decision? Also, there are the two general questions:
Why would the BoE raise interest rates?
- higher than desired inflation
- normalizing interest rates after an economic recovery Why would the BoE decrease interest rates?
- lower than desired inflation
- to stimulate the economy I am working off these scenarios for brexit (as determined in forecasts for other questions):
9%   deal brexit on 29 March (given this, probability for: decreased rate 5%, hold 80%, increase 15%)
9%   no deal Brexit on 29 March (given this, probability for: decreased rate 25%, hold 70%, increase 5%)
72% brexit after 29 March (no indication of deal or no deal) (given this, probability for: decreased rate 5%, hold 90%, increase 5%)
10% indication of no deal brexit after 29 March (given this, probability for: decreased rate 20%, hold 80%, increase 0%) Calculating probabilities of the branches of the decision tree and summing up by outcome gives me the forecast.
Maybe a bit of a chance to loosen rates now with Brexit fears and weakening economy

inflation is in a downard trend and that is the UK Bank's main mandate to control so tightenting is less of an issue. Also, the brexit situation isn't moving forward in a positve way, meaning they could lower the rate. There are two more meeting left on the docket.  The option implied probability has the media at its current rate from what I can tell. https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/statistics/option-implied-probability-density-functions

CPI fell 0.2 to 2.0% in December 
https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices
The MPC may discuss increased risks of 'no deal' exit in next issue Feb 7, but a 0.25% drop by April 1 seems extreme and nothing points upward thus far...
https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/2018/december-2018

Cutting the rate looks desperate - 'saving the UK government some money on FI bonds', why? - and raising it when inflation is flat also looks desperate - 'we really need some hot money flowing into FI bonds'. No action is the 'no surprises' option.
Smart money rising on 'no change'. Straddling remainder.
Updating to account for market expectations posted here: https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/bank-of-england-watch-tool.html
Based on the COE probability calculator: https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/bank-of-england-watch-tool.html
Increasing slightly for no change, mainly because I expect Brexit to be delayed.

Lowering probability of an increase from 17% to 15% on the back of the recent failure of May's Brexit plan, which spells more uncertainty surrounding Brexit, which I expect to keep inflation in check (ergo, less need for the BoE to do it).
Smart money slowly shifting lower, to include a cut by April 1. Leading UK equities indication suggests a pause if ROC(105) < 3%, and possible cut if ROC(105) remains < -3%: http://schrts.co/RmEuFyBS

There are only two meetings before April 1st, as per https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/news/2018/september/monetary-policy-committee-dates-for-2019 (February 7th and March 21st) so, not much time to for further than 1.00%. The conditioning path by the BoE in November expected 0.8% in Q1 2019 which seems in line with an increasingly "hawkish" chief-economist (https://www.economist.com/britain/2018/11/17/andy-haldane-the-maverick-at-the-bank-of-england-who-could-one-day-run-it).
However, CPI for December was 2.1%, down from 2.3% in Nov (Oil prices), which might indicate lower inflationary pressures. The BoE expected an excess in demand to justify the rise of interest rates (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/2018/december-2018), but uncertainties and potential delays in trade relationships with the EU might have an impact. My forecast is that with less pressure, more uncertainty, it is most likely that rates will remain unchanged in next two meetings
adjusting for more margin of potential actions after last weeks' vote for a no-deal brexit.

Current trends all point to no change, but shit happens
(Review Feb 8)

Increasing no change bin slightly at the expense of increased bank rate probability, because I think uncertainty has increased so an increase has become less likely. Will need an update on 8th February with the next MPC meeting and inflation report.

BoE will be cautious against brexit background but if Brexit gets abandoned through referendum, economy will strengthen, if as most likely some fudged brexit on the soft side then rates will be edged up - very wide range of possible outcomes, but slight bias towards bit of tightening

Are you kidding me. With all that Brexit drama there will be no move anymore until a.) things get settled (1% chance), b.) Brexit gets postponed beyond March 29, 2019 (24% chance) or c.) the hard Brexit on March 29, 2019 (75% chance)

Time frame is very short - basically meeting 2.7.19, where I think Economic data lends toward a rate hike during 2019. However, with Brexit negotiations not going well, the probability of a chaotic EU exit could cause a cautious BoE to cut rates 3.21. I view both as low probability and odds that MPC sits on their hands is high.

The Bank of England has expressed its intention to raise the bank rate again by 2020 with multiple rate rises (of 0.25% each if the pattern since 1997 is to be followed) in 2019. The next quarterly report will happen in March which will be too early to have assessed the impact of brexit, but the BofE might know if there is a deal in place. In the situation that there is a good deal or no brexit at all, the economy will be looking up and their intended rate rise could happen. If there is no deal or lingering uncertainty eg. another referendum or an article 50 extension, investment might remain subdued which would put pressure on the bank to drop rates. The bank has already warned it doesn't intend to drop rates but would prefer to stay the course.

With the Brexit deadline getting closer, the BOE seems to have adopted a neutral stance amid uncertainty with the deal. Additionally, the resignation of Dominic Raab as Britain's Brexit Minister added to the political turmoil of the whole Brexit process. This could support the idea that the BOE would continue with its neutral stance until the exit deal with the EU is probably passed in Parliament, which in turn could ease the uncertainty regarding the U.K. economy's performance, making them more comfortable to proceed with a rate hike depending on the behavior of inflation and especially GDP growth.
Life is uncertain, particularly now with Brexit and other imponderables. This will probably restrain the BoE (not wanting to upset market) but they may be provoked to move dramatically.

UK much like the rest of the world is crumbling, Thank Putin for everything.  If you think things are bad in France, just wait.  you haven’t seen Chaos unfold quite like this,,,,,It spreads like wildfire, so be prepared, and afraid.

A change of + or - 0.25% is conceivable over 2+ months because of political uncertainty and/or inflation. Current or slightly higher inflation may trigger an increase in February, but I'm guessing there's strong pressure for stability

The BOE wants to raise rates, but does not want to be a destabilizing influence in the present moment. The national conversation of Brexit will continue to get more and more uncertain, possibly with near-hysteria headlines as March approaches.
BOE will likely err on the side of caution and keep rates steady at .75. To reduce them is to signal something is "wrong" and that BOE knows something no one else does (regardless of the veracity of that supposition). Raising rates adds to transition upheavals by now making borrowing more expensive - that will just add to the litany of complaints in the papers. 
Better to stay out of it and just signal "steady as she goes"/"everything will all work out"/"we'll keep a close eye on things and adjust as appropriate", etc etc.

Let’s start with the statistics of voting to calculate our base rates. Based on the records  of the monetary policy committee voting history, since 1997, 81% of the times the committee voted to maintain the bank rate, 8% to increase and 11% to reduce. Putting more weight to monetary policy voting behavior of 2008-2018, the probabilities are set accordingly: 87% maintain,6% increase and 7% reduce.  Since recording in 1997, the committee only voted for an increase of +0,25%. In case there would be an increase, we can exclude an increase of more than 1%.  For a reduce there are different stretches, from -0,25% till even -1,5%. When excluding the years of the financial crisis, the reduce was -0,25% or -0,5% with more votes for a small reduce. When looking at the voting behavior after the financial crisis, there was only a reduce of -0,25%. In case there would be a reduce, we can exclude less than 0,26% The Bank of England states that to meet their inflation target of 2%, they need to judge how much people intend to save and spend given the current interest rates.  So, this raises the following question: Will people start spending less than save given the current interest rates when Britain will leave the EU on 29 March 2019?  According to this article of the Financial Times, households are spending & borrowing more than saving. The article states that one danger for the economy is that households will save more again after the 29th of March, which could hurt the wider economy. Now, will the Bank Of England react before the 1st of April with a decrease of the Bank rate? There’s great uncertainty on how the Brexit will be implemented and how it will impact businesses and households. For now, I would see the voting committee to rather wait and follow spending/saving behaviour up to the March 29. 
source FT = https://www.ft.com/content/cf51e840-7147-11e7-93ff-99f383b09ff9
Can't change things at this time
Why would there be any added instability with an increase?

More than 1% is a disaster scenario which would be brought on  by severe oscillation in the value of the pound, and I think they will tie everything down with lead chains to prevent that, certainly as of April. Inflation is currently about 2.2% so very low rates would also be fairly catastrophic - withdrawal of money from gilts etc would follow. It'll be hard but i expect them to pull out all the stops to not change anything for quite a while.
Higher odds of uncertainty lasting till timeframe, and they keep rates on hold.
I'm thinking this goes to the wire or gets a continuation and the BoE waits to see what happens. Affirming.

The MPC is hedging... does not want to make predictions because of volatility re. Brexit: no change there!

Will political turmoil curb inflation at 2.0% or will monetary intervention be needed?
https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices - 2.2% in November.

"INTEREST RATES
As prices fall, the pressure on the Bank to raise rates will wane. Even so, interest rates are expected to climb in 2019, with 28 of 47 respondents forecasting an increase from the present 0.75 per cent; 12 of them expect two quarter-point increases to 1.25 per cent. There was a spread of responses from Brexiteers, who modelled variations of a managed no deal. Mr Minford expects to see a big increase in rates to 1.5 per cent as wage growth of more than 4 per cent offsets the deflationary effect of a sterling appreciation to $1.35. Mr Lilico, who anticipates an economic slowdown next year, sees rates cut to 0.25 per cent as wage growth slows to 1.5 per cent. Mr Lyons expects sterling, wages and rates to hold steady and Ms Lea expects only a single quarter-point increase. On balance, households should expect an increase in borrowing costs. Unless, according to Remainer economists, there is a hard Brexit, when rates are more likely to be cut, at least temporarily. Respondents got it right last year, accurately predicting that rates would end 2019 above the then level of 0.5 per cent."
https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/from-brexit-to-the-bank-whats-in-store-for-2019-xs5pch27d?shareToken=b1508d3a807f64a42f685abf870c483f

A 25bps rate hike to boost GBP is the most possible scenario. If Brexit was resolved, BOE would raise rates more aggressively. If hard Brexit happens then a rate hike would be the only way to help GBP. I would vote for more than 1.00%, but I do not want to be so far out of consensus

Forward overnight interest rate swap curve is suggesting 0.75% (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/statistics/yield-curves). So I am taking that as the most likely outcome. From there, I think the question is "which side do I want more protection on?" I think this becomes a Brexit question. Knowing that a "No Deal" Brexit is still on the table, a rate hike could be detrimental to UK sentiment (Davis, et. al, "Vanguard Economic & Market Outlook for 2019", 2019, p21). Based on recent developments (pending No Confidence Vote, possible second referendum, etc.) I think the March Brexit deadline could very well pass without a deal and trigger a downgrade (33% chance). I believe a downgrade would force the BOE to raise rates to continue attracting capital and support the pound. Either way, I think there is too much uncertainty for the BOE to act before the Brexit deadline. Therefore, I think the forward curve is going to be the best predictor.

ING analysis finds this unlikely in this timeframe as posted by @michalbod. More of the uncertainty seems to be on the downside (chance of lowering rates) rather than raising them given the volatile environment. https://think.ing.com/snaps/three-scenarios-for-the-bank-of-england-as-rates-left-on-hold/

I think there will be no deal on brexit on the current terms negotiated by PM May and EU Commissioners. BoE will be forced to cut the interest rate as a stimulus for economic growth. The only odd is related to a German intervention because UK is double-chaines linked to German supply chain.

The Bank of England warned that Brexit uncertainties had “intensified considerably” over the past month as it left interest rates unchanged at 0.75 per cent.
https://www.ft.com/content/1995658a-044a-11e9-99df-6183d3002ee1 It merely repeated that it had said at its November meeting that if there was a smooth Brexit with a transition period, the economy was likely to need roughly one quarter point interest rate rise a year to keep inflation anchored to its target of 2 per cent.

UK consumer inflation rate cools slightly in November
https://www.ft.com/content/ff7c17c8-036f-11e9-9d01-cd4d49afbbe3 Britain’s inflation rate fell again in November, providing a further boost to living standards as businesses have not passed on higher wage costs to consumers.
The consumer price index rose by 2.3 per cent in the year to November, down from a 2.4 per cent rate of annual change in October. This was in line with City economists’ expectations, according to a poll by Reuters.

Looks like the only Brexit happening by March might be a hard Brexit, which would call for a rate cut (probably only 25bp, not 50), but most likely there is a delay in Brexit and no changes in rates.
Swings beyond this seem unrealistic at this time.
I think the UK will remain in the EU and therefore rate will remain stable.  If not, equal chances of rate going anywhere higher.
I believe the rate will be set lower to help keep the economy going.

Updating due to increased uncertainty,
1) Michael Saunders sending mixed signals https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-boe-saunders/bank-of-englands-saunders-sees-higher-rates-if-brexit-goes-smoothly-idUKKCN1NR2E0
2) support for Brexit deal is uncertain, raising chances of a no deal scenario which could even put lower rates back on the table.

Brexit will probably lead to higher consumer prices which will lead to increased inflation. Bank of England will try to keep control over inflation with higher interest rates as already done recently in small steps by 0.25%
Shifting around a bit because high inflation in the country may constrain the Bank of England's freedom of action.
Lack of confidence and uncertainty in the private sector and the general public due to Brexit may prevent the The Bank of England’s Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) from changing interest rates.

Basically hinges on Brexit and economy. Brexit vote is on December 11th. I think Brexit gets extended out and it will take until after April 1 in any case for the Bank of England to act.[1]  Hedging 20% against a hard no deal Brexit and likely reduction of rates that might require until the vote. Also putting in a bit of a hedge in case this works out and there is less uncertainty by putting 10% on an increase. Current economic consensus forecasts seem to think the economy should be about same.[2] Will likely cut off the 2% off the ends after the vote. “We still expect the Bank of England to hike around once a year and our base case is that the next hike will arrive in May 2019, so after the UK formally leaves the EU. It may be earlier (February) if the economy continues to surprise on the upside. On the other hand, the Bank of England also stated that Brexit uncertainty has gone up among businesses, as nearly 20% of companies now think Brexit is the key source of uncertainty. This probably explains why there is no growth in business investments.” “The rate decision also depends on the outcome of the Brexit negotiations. One box in the Inflation Report explains the Bank of England’s reaction in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The overall takeaway is that while the Bank of England cannot offset lower potential growth due to changes in the supply side of the economy, it can react to demand changes. Our view is that a ‘no-deal Brexit’ would most likely hit the economy through lower demand due to lower business confidence, which would most likely force the Bank of England to ease monetary policy by cutting the Bank Rate.”[3] [1] https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/nov/30/brexit-eu-dismisses-mays-claim-that-deal-might-be-renegotiated [2] https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/757823/Forecomp_November_2018_PDF.pdf [3] https://www.fxstreet.com/news/bank-of-england-rate-hike-expected-by-may-2019-but-depends-on-brexit-danske-bank-201811011911
Too much flux in international markets, the MPC will ask a pretty penny.
With all the uncertainty around Brexit the government will likely want to keep monetary policy tight in the months after.

A move of more than 50bps down is unlikely. The pre-emptive supportive following the referendum result was a 25bps. Unlikely that we see more than this given a lack of data points so soon after Brexit. 
Additionally, the top end will not be in play, given the pessimistic post Brexit forecasts announced by the BOE this week for all scenarios. A rate rise between now and exit, or in the immediate post Brexit aftermath is highly unlikely.
There may be a cut following Brexit (as there was following the referendum result), but without any data points to use in decision making, I feel this is a less likely option 
Maintaining current rate is most likely scenario.

Brexit is a disaster.  Yes this could provide a sterling crisis with short term hike in rates to punish those shorting GBP, but i think this would an unlikely response from the BoE - rather I see cutting rates in response to a potential economic crisis much more possible, although still a relatively lower chance than stable rates.

The base rate is expected to rise over the coming years at a 'gradual pace', most likely in increments of 0.25% towards a 2.00% goal assuming the economy continues to recover (see trend https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/boeapps/database/Bank-Rate.asp).  The next rise is tipped to be in mid-2019 (so after the 1st of April 2019), thus I'm expecting no change from the current rate of 0.75%.  Possible complications:
 - an earlier increase to 1.00% due to good economic performance.  I think this is fairly unlikely given the track record of slow recovery and the uncertainly over Brexit.  On the flip-side this could be deliberately squeezed in before Brexit to signal confidence.  Say 10%.
 - a pre-emptive change as we get closer to Brexit and the likely effects start to become clear.  Again unlikely because, frankly, I don't think anything's going to become clear until the last minute.  Say 8% likelihood of a drop to 0.50% and 2% of an increase to 1.00%.
 - a reactive change due to unfolding events in the days leading up to Brexit itself.  This is very unlikely because (Monday) the 1st of April 2019 is only a few days after (Friday) the 29th of March 2019, but if panic begins in the days before Brexit it seems plausible a change might be rushed through in time.  Say 4%, split evenly between all the other possible answers.
Bank of England will try and stimulate the economy following a disastrous Brexit and ensuing recession

Thinking they are going to drop rates because of the consequences of the rolling dumpster fire otherwise known as Brexit. That said, inflation is at 2.7% so they may feel too constrained to lower rates to stimulate the economy.

GEnerally inertia for rate changes is high. Limited chance of two rate changes up or down over 3 MPC meetings between now and the 1 April. The most likely outcome is the same as now i.e. 0.75%, with some possibility of rate cut either way.
Brexit is due to happen at end of March, but there wont be an MPC until afterwards

It is highly likely the BoE will be pulling in different directions with decision makers calling for caution as well as loosening of monetary policy.   The govenor will likely dither causing interest rates to remain the same.
Brexit, deal or no deal, will most likely put more upward pressure on consumer prices.
As Brexit deal is announced and there will be changes in regulations, UK exiting EU can cause Bank of England to increase the interest rate to control money supply and protect against inflation.
Depends on Brexit. No deal; lower rates to soften the blow. Deal: same or higher rates.

This forecast includes (a) some sort of order leading up to Brexit, say 95%; (b) trade wars will not precipitate any great drop in demand in the first quarter of 2019, say 90%; (c) CPI remains above 2% (2.2 in October; next release: Dec. 19), say at least 50% probability of an increase; (d) forecasting outliers of, say 5% or less, seems dull - and may be counter-productive when accuracy is assessed using error-squared methods.
(review forecast Dec. 20th)
Guardian newspaper, Nov. 1:
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/nov/01/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-no-deal-brexit
Mark Carney, governor of Bank of England: “Since the nature of EU withdrawal is not known at present, and its impact on the balance of demand, supply and the exchange rate cannot be determined in advance, the monetary policy response will not be automatic and could be in either direction,” 
James Smith, economist at banking group ING, said it was far more likely that rates would be cut if negotiations ended in failure. “In a ‘no deal’ scenario, the Bank has suggested rates could go in either direction. However, given the wide-scale disruption that would likely occur, we suspect policymakers would ‘look through’ any spike in prices caused by a weaker pound, and cut interest rates or increase quantitative easing fairly swiftly.”
Announcing the latest decision of its rate-setting committee on Thursday, the Bank said the MPC voted unanimously to keep the base rate at 0.75%. On the assumption that there is a smooth Brexit, the MPC thinks it will need to raise rates gradually from their current level of 0.75% in order to keep inflation close to its 2% target. Threadneedle Street believes businesses will unlock investment that has been put on hold while there has been uncertainty about the future UK-EU relationship, pushing growth up from 1.5% in 2018 to 1.7% in each of the next two years.
Brexit means uncertainty even with a deal. Extreme times might require more than a +.25% increase after March.

With two more meetings of the Bank of England between now and April 1, I believe it is very likely that the rates would be raised once more by a quarter percentage point.  I hedge the prediction with a possible dropping of rates if the outcome of the Brexit process is unsuccessful.
I don't know...will they need to raise in order to defend the currency, or lower to spur the economy?
Not going to happen until at least May with Brexit uncertainty

I think it unlikely they will lower rates or raise rates given the uncertainty.

The Bank of England voted unanimously to leave the Bank Rate unchanged at 0.75 percent on November 1st 2018, in line with market expectations. Policymakers said that if the economy continues to develop in line with forecasts, further tightening will be appropriate. They too an increase earlier this year, could do so in February as they contemplate Brexit
While the Bank Rate may increase, MPC is likely to be cautious in terms of how much as the economic growth has to be maintained while prices need to be in check.
With all of the Brexit/economic uncertainty, multiple hikes seem unlikely.

We have one inflation report and two MPC meetings scheduled before the question closes. 
The latest reported inflation is 2.4%, moderately above the 2% Bank of England target. The latest letter about inflation being above target signals for an slow increase in Bank Rate ("All members agree that any future increases in Bank Rate are expected to be at a gradual pace and to a limited extent.", https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/letter/2018/governor-cpi-letter-080218.pdf?la=en&hash=39D0CD86D203550BF0A8B18EF7235B1583A86503). If, at the time of the Feb 2019 report, inflation keeps moving back towards the target according to what the Bank of England predicts, this will lend support to keep Bank Rate stable at 0.75%. Conversely, if economic development does not pan out as predicted or the Brexit deal details provide additional uncertainty or economic strain, the BoE might be forced to raise Bank Rate earlier. At this stage I think it is close to a coin toss between steady and slightly increased rates. I am forecasting slightly higher probability of increased Bank rate compared to the "Wisdom of the Crowd"-average forecasts because I think the global economic climate puts upward pressure on interest rates everywhere. A major update of this forecast is in order when new inflation data or Brexit deal details become available.
I expect a rate rise in early 2019

A big factor in this outcome is the result of the Brexit negotiations, obviously. With a hard Brexit in March, an interest rate cut would not be unrealistic. A more favorable Brexit outcome would point more to the rate remaining at the current .5-.75 range, or maybe even one more increase. My forecast attempts to interpolate these two scenarios, and I weight them roughly 40-60 (hard versus soft Brexit, respectively).

I'm guessing they lower or hold interest rates due to Brexit uncertainty.

With inflation set to ease a bit and with Brexit tensions remaining at a standstill and a no deal likely to have a finality for policy implications that the original ref vote did not carry. Rate rise could come but not likely before 1 April 2019.  "However, the meeting and accompanying inflation report demonstrated that the bank has a very clear tightening bias. Its assessment is that demand in the economy will grow over the next three years at a faster pace than the rate of supply growth, leading to rising domestic cost pressures. As a result, the Bank of England expects that further rate rises will be necessary to return inflation to its 2% target." https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/business/uk-may-raise-rates-in-may-883438.html "The Bank's comments came as its Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) voted 9-0 to leave rates unchanged at 0.75%. " Unanimous vote  https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/nov/01/no-uk-interest-rate-rise-plenty-no-deal-brexit-warnings-bank-of-england https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-06/what-a-brexit-deal-can-and-can-t-do-for-the-british-economy
If Brexit is disruptive ie 'hard Brexit', BoE may need to reduce the rate to provide support to a faltering economy. Short of that, they will stick to the intended plan of gradually rising rates.

I agree with the post by @dsarin, most of which is reprinted below for participants' convenience:  'Allan Monks, UK economist at JPMorgan, said the BoE was clearly not going to raise rates while there was still Brexit uncertainty, but “the Inflation Report is hinting that a hike in May could be too late”. Christian Schulz, an economist at Citi, said the BoE had given four hawkish messages in its Inflation Report and news conference, including earlier-than-expected excess demand in the forecasts, the need to take account of fiscal stimulus, predictions of above-target inflation and a suggestion the next rate rise might be sooner than markets expect.  “As the MPC is once again raring to go once Brexit uncertainty fades, we bring forward the next 0.25 percentage point hike to 1 per cent to 2 May 2019,” he said.' https://www.ft.com/content/d7a5b818-ddcb-11e8-8f50-cbae5495d92b My interpretation of these comments is that rates are frozen by Brexit uncertainty but inflation risks are high enough to force a move before May.

UK Inflation is rising and the economy is doing quite well even with all the uncertainties of Brexit.  BoE has said they would have raised rates if not for the imminent Brexit deal.  I think there is a decent chance a deal is announced with no consequences aka "a non-Brexit Brexit" and rates are raised after that once.
I think England will not want to project any instability, and therefore will do everything possible to maintain the status quo.
BOE will want to do little to shock the economy during transition period.

For me it is hard to imagine scenario in which rates would go down. If there is "hard Brexit" (which for me is more likely scenario) GBP will go down, In this case rates won't be lowered to not sink GBP even further. I even expect slim chance of defending GBP by raising rates which I gave 10% probability. Most likely scenario for me is that BoE will just wait to see Brexit outcome to decide on path forward. @dsarin any thoughts on above? You are great on economic questions and I believe based in London

Rates are generally forecast to increase (from the current rate of 0.75% in November 2018), so I have estimated a greater probability of them being above 0.75% (55%) in April 2019 than being below 0.75% (45%). I would be more confident of rate going up if the outcome of Brexit negotiations were clearer - but as Mark Carney (Governor of the Bank of England) has said, rates may go up or down in support of the Brexit outcomes - http://uk.businessinsider.com/bank-of-england-interest-rate-decision-and-inflation-report-2018-11. So, at this stage, although I think the chances of rates being higher is more than the chances of rates being lower, the difference is not that great - and there is I think a reasonable chance (1 in 5, 20%) that they will stay the same until the UK formally exits the EU, with the Bank making no changes until after the leaving date (29th March 2019).
British people just don't do big moves!
